title: Nonorganic Hearing Loss with Underlying Chronic Otitis Media
chief_complaint: I have constant ringing in both ears, but it's louder in the left. I also have pain and a feeling of fullness in my left ear that has been bothering me for years.

problem_summary.onset: 11 years prior (2003-2004) while deployed in Iraq.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral tinnitus (worse left); Left ear pain and fullness.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant bilateral tinnitus (loud steady ringing), otalgia (left), aural fullness (left), stress.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Tinnitus causes great stress and perceived hearing difficulty.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking relief from tinnitus and ear pain; monitoring hearing.

history.present_illness: Patient reports 11-year history of chronic left ear infections starting during 14-month deployment in Iraq. Reports continued pain and fullness in the left ear.
history.otologic_history: Chronic left ear infections. No history of otosurgery.
history.noise_exposure_history: Excessive noise exposure from frequent cannon fire outside medical tent in Iraq (2003-2004).
history.medical_psych_history: Reports stress related to tinnitus. Denies dizziness.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Initial testing showed significant functional overlay (nonorganic hearing loss). Pure-tone averages (PTA) were significantly worse than Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT), indicating exaggerated hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: After significant reinstruction, valid thresholds were obtained. Right ear shows mild SNHL sloping to moderately-severe. Left ear shows moderate SNHL sloping to severe. SRTs are now in agreement with PTAs.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear is normal (Type A). Left ear is flat (Type B) with large canal volume, consistent with tympanic membrane perforation.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient initially presented with nonorganic hearing loss, evidenced by significant PTA-SRT discrepancies. Following reinstruction, valid testing revealed a mild-to-moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear and a moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Immittance testing identified a likely tympanic membrane perforation in the left ear (large canal volume). Word recognition scores are excellent bilaterally once valid thresholds were established.
counseling_points: Explain that the second round of testing provided a much clearer picture of your true hearing levels, which are better than the initial test suggested.
Discuss the results showing a likely hole (perforation) in the left eardrum, which explains the 'flat' reading on the pressure test and likely contributes to the history of infections.
Recommend a follow-up with an otologist (ENT) to manage the left ear perforation and chronic infections.
Discuss hearing protection strategies given the history of noise exposure and current sensorineural hearing loss.
Review the tinnitus as a symptom of the hearing loss and noise exposure; stress reduction techniques may help manage the perception of the ringing.
notes_for_actor: During the initial phase of the exam, display hesitation or inconsistency in button pressing to simulate the functional overlay.
Express visible stress regarding the tinnitus.
After the audiologist provides 'reinstruction' (firm but kind clarification of instructions), become cooperative and consistent to allow for the valid 'Post-reinstruction' results.
